"Representative appointments are sought from 3 motives. 1. ambition 2. personal interest. 3. public good. Unhappily the two first are proved by experience to be most prevalent. Hence the candidates who feel them, particularly, the second, are most industrious, and most successful in pursuing their object: and forming often a majority in the legislative Councils, with interested views, contrary to the interest, and views, of their Constituents, join in a perfidious sacrifice of the latter to the former. A succeeding election it might be supposed, would displace the offenders, and repair the mischief. But how easily are base and selfish measures, masked by pretexts of public good and apparent expediency? How frequently will a repetition of the same arts and industry which succeeded in the first instance, again prevail on the unwary to misplace their confidence?

How frequently too will the honest but unenlightened representative be the dupe of a favorite leader, veiling his selfish views under the professions of public good, and varnishing his sophistical arguments with the glowing colours of popular eloquence?" - James Madison

"This is a very sad thing, but it started in the 1960s with the Civil Rights movement and the integration of public schools. Poor whites, especially in the south and midwest, who had traditionally voted Democrat against the Rich and lived with the pride of 'we may be poor and uneducated, but at least we're not black' suddenly didn't have that anymore. They felt betrayed by the Democrats and didn't have anybody to cling to.

That's where Nixon's Southern Strategy came in and was the first time that the Republican Party allied itself with Conservative Christian Values. Specifically they started appealing to ignorance. They preached that it was okay to be stupid and anybody who said different was an elitist. When the Republicans tapped into this, they were able to make inroads into previously inaccessible territory and since then, they have focused exclusively on 'The way things ought to be'.

This post-integration period saw increasing attendance at newly formed Conservative Evangelical Schools that catered primarily to poor whites. These schools have tied authority and religion together in a way that had been impossible before. The "Prosperity Gospel", which I understand is practically unheard of in Europe, ties in Prosperity as the result of hard work and blind faith in God. Because of nearly 40 years of this kind of teaching in private schools, for large sections of the country, the concept of riches and blessings are synonymous and consequently, the rich must be saints, because God has blessed them so much. Hard Work and Personal Responsibility became the watch-words of the right, and anything that is seen as trying to avoid either (for example: Abortion, Contraception, Cures for STDs) is viewed as sinful and evil. Also anything that takes away God's blessings from the Rich (and lotto winners) is evil.

This, "coincidentally", is about the same time you start seeing an increase in the public perception of Unions as promoting rewards for being lazy, so literally the only place that the poor have left to congregate and join together at are their right-wing conservative Churches. Previously this had been the view of the Right (and actually led to the rise of "The Family", whose earliest members were involved in evangelizing to the rich and the leaders who could actually make a difference and not coincidentally, were also involved in Strike-Breaking activities in the 1930s), but it obviously didn't have traction with the working-class for the reason that's in their very name: They are the Working Class. You can't really tell them that they are lazy without introducing some kind of divider.

That divider came about with the introduction of the "Lower Middle Class" as a concept and it was into that class that everybody who sent their children to private (Christian) schools, and who could buy things (even on credit) were in. The Middle Class in America never really grew as a percentage of the population and isn't really shrinking. The percentage of people who are genuinely middle class is the same as it's always been, it's that in the 60s, the definition of middle class changed to include all of the labor that had previously been proud to be considered working class. (In the same sense that the number of College Graduates isn't really increasing. The number of people going to college has gone up (especially For-Profit schools, Trade Schools, and job-training institutions calling themselves colleges), but it's still only about 20% of the population that actually graduates from University. That's how high it's always been.)

With all those people suddenly in the "middle class", it was suddenly easier to demonize the working class as lazy, because all of those people who had been working class before had suddenly made it and were middle class. So there's your divider: The Lower Middle Class. (Of course, all these Middle Class Americans have also been taught that there isn't really any class divide in the US, despite our divides being deeper and sharper than any in modern Europe.)

This, also "coincidentally", is also about the same time that you start hearing people rail against knowledge and against science, because that would shake the foundations of the religious hold over these people. If the Bible isn't true, then everything they know about the world is wrong and their world-view doesn't work.

Also, it's about this same time that the popular notion that everybody has a voice and everybody has an opinion and all opinions are equally valid came about. To give strength to people who before would have simply said 'I don't know, so I'll leave it to people who do'. Now prior knowledge of a subject isn't a prerequisite for having a valid opinion on the matter.

So really, ultimately, it's all about about class warfare: The upper classes have successfully executed a divide and conquer strategy in order to protect themselves from the the ghost of communism. Basically, Fascism came to America wrapped in a cross and a flag and it suckered in 36% of the population." - another very intelligent guy on SomethingAwful

This semester's pretty close to over, so I might as well evaluate it, even if it's just so I can look back on this post in however many months/years and see what I was thinking. I'm pretty bad with remembering things from the past distinctly, so I wish I'd kept a journal throughout highschool or something. I guess this sort of thing will have to do.

Thesis class was harder than I was expecting. The actual work for the class (the papers themselves etc) wasn't bad at all, but researching for this stupid project was probably the longest thing I've ever done for one paper. I've read at least 30 books and articles, and I still don't feel like that's anywhere near enough. Fortunately I've still got half a year to go before the paper has to be turned in. Note for future: that one kid is doing a paper on NJ punk rock subculture in the 80s/90s, and that is cool.

Byzantine Empire: Waaaaaay more difficult than the fall of Rome class or possibly even the Hellenistic period class, simply because it was so long, covering some thousand or so years. I'm impressed how I'm able to remember pretty much all the important information from Diocletian up to Michael VI Bringas. Let's see how long that will last. Really interesting stuff, too bad I'll never use any of it in my life again. I kind of want to tell somebody about all of this history though.

Japanese 302: Sociology done in Japanese. Was there any organization to this class at all? No. Big mess. At least I made some friends, although I'm sure since they're not from around here that's not going to last long after college. Oh yeah, and we watched Princess Mononoke, and that's also cool. And Bleach is bad.

Geology: Actually very interesting. Too bad my professor is a climate change denialist, because otherwise the class might actually be fun. That doesn't really surprise me too much; I wanted to be a scientist when I was a kid. I probably should have followed in that path to be honest, since at least that has job prospects.

Overall this has been a pretty weird semester. I've had to double down on homework, which I didn't even know I could do considering every semester I'm already bogged down. I wish I'd actually been able to have some semblance of a social life this semester, but unlike in high school where I just was lazy and wanted to play video games or was too shy, I actually couldn't do anything now because I have so much work to do. That's pretty disappointing, because I've been stuck in an introspective rut for the past half-year, and I think it's gearing me towards wanting to be more sociable. Not extroverted, but just not as much of a shut in as I am. At the same time, I'm a workaholic, and I actually get nervous and annoyed when I don't have a deadline hanging over me and a heavy workload to get done and a perfectly timed schedule whereby everything is maximally divvied up. So I don't think I'm going to run the risk of becoming some party animal. I wouldn't like that anyway. 

I've got too many books I want to read and too many movies I want to see. Still need to get around to reading some theological things. I think I'll have more free time to do what I want to/need to do after college is over. Of course, then I have to actually work permanently, and that's...probably not going to happen.

I think I sit around and romanticize to classical music too much.

On the plus side, at least I'm not a juggalo.

If you ever wonder why liberals often don't show up at the polls on election day, it's very simple. Liberals view America as a country in constant flux, which can use the government to correct various injustices. Conservatives, meanwhile, tend to view American society as good enough as it is right now, and any incoming change is thus either scary or a threat to their current way of life and rights. And it's much easier to motivate people to come out and vote in favor of protecting something already there (think of how many people came out in favor of Prop 8, they were protecting the status quo) than to get people to come out and vote in favor of something not there, which has no guarantee of success. This results in all the whiny teenagers and 20-somethings who say "Why vote, it doesn't matter and it doesn't change anything!!!"

Tying into my previous post, the best way to drive progress forward is to implement large and extensive programs at such a fast pace that once they become entrenched, people will come out and vote in favor of protecting them. If the Democrats would stop being idiots and start playing the rhetoric as "Republicans want to take away your rights to x, y, z, come out and vote to protect your rights!" they'd get a lot more done.

If there's one thing above all that the past 20 years have shown me, it's that incrementalism does not work when there is a for-profit media that caters to specific audiences. The reason FDR and JFK and LBJ could push through liberal policies, and why European nations continue to function, is because they didn't/don't have Fox News and AM radio to deal with.

The only way to get progressive ideals enacted in American society going forward must be to blitzkrieg them through Congress at as fast a pace as possible and in as large an amount as possible, so that they become so ingrained and entrenched in the American psyche that they're near impossible to overturn. Let me just clarify what that last post means, because I realize something so vague probably means nothing to anyone who actually reads this LJ from time to time for whatever reason. I've always been rather indifferent to emotional things, or at least I've been good at projecting that sort of aloofness even when I was actually upset about something. Everyone does that to some extent, but since I'm naturally a cynical and sarcastic person it's fused into my general personality. To some extent, it really is true that I am indifferent to a lot of things that other people strive for in life, like wealth or love. To some extent, I'm also probably lying to myself.

What annoys/worries me is that whereas I used to be fully confident in my indifference, lately I've been feeling like I care. Anyone who's watched Seinfeld probably remembers that scene where Jerry started crying because he actually cared about a girlfriend ("What is this salty discharge!?" "This is horrible! I care!" etc). I'm not at that level. But I don't like having to reevaluate what I care about and what I don't.

I'm pretty sure this is mostly because I'll be graduating in a year and that means I'll actually have to confront the world like an adult instead of someone locked into a very easy, annually repeating system that I've grown comfortable with. Except I feel like everyone else would have gone through their dumb ~*fInDiNg MySeLf*~ phases during high school and early college, but since I've always just sat there and looked at everyone else and went "Heh, what a bunch of losers, worrying about their First World Problems while Real People have Real Problems around the world, like starving Africans or oppressed North Koreans" and then patted my back and felt smug and superior about how I didn't have to deal with the garbage everyone else had to deal with, I never got to actually deal with the garbage everyone else had to deal with. It doesn't help that I've always also been extremely devoted to academics and that took up all of my thinking time.

In short I am actually human and that's annoying.
I think I'm losing my grip on my stoicism and it's starting to annoy/worry me.

"But the function of dress as an evidence of ability to pay does not end with simply showing that the wearer consumes valuable goods in excess of what is required for physical comfort. Simple conspicuous waste of goods is effective and gratifying as far as it goes; it is good prima facie evidence of pecuniary success, and consequently prima facie evidence of social worth. But dress has subtler and more far-reaching possibilities than this crude, first-hand evidence of wasteful consumption only. If, in addition to showing that the wearer can afford to consume freely and uneconomically, it can also be shown in the same stroke that he or she is not under the necessity of earning a livelihood, the evidence of social worth is enhanced in a very considerable degree. Our dress, therefore, in order to serve its purpose effectually, should not only be expensive, but it should also make plain to all observers that the wearer is not engaged in any kind of productive labor. In the evolutionary process by which our system of dress has been elaborated into its present admirably perfect adaptation to its purpose, this subsidiary line of evidence has received due attention. A detailed examination of what passes in popular apprehension for elegant apparel will show that it is contrived at every point to convey the impression that the wearer does not habitually put forth any useful effort. It goes without saying that no apparel can be considered elegant, or even decent, if it shows the effect of manual labor on the part of the wearer, in the way of soil or wear. The pleasing effect of neat and spotless garments is chiefly, if not altogether, due to their carrying the suggestion of leisure-exemption from personal contact with industrial processes of any kind. Much of the charm that invests the patent-leather shoe, the stainless linen, the lustrous cylindrical hat, and the walking-stick, which so greatly enhance the native dignity of a gentleman, comes of their pointedly suggesting that the wearer cannot when so attired bear a hand in any employment that is directly and immediately of any human use. Elegant dress serves its purpose of elegance not only in that it is expensive, but also because it is the insignia of leisure. It not only shows that the wearer is able to consume a relatively large value, but it argues at the same time that he consumes without producing."

And now I've finished all my Persian history books, so here's a rundown of those.  Except shorter this time.

-Life in the Ancient Near East 3100-332 BCE (Snell) - Fairly dry stuff, basically details in a condensed manner the political and social history of Sumer/Egypt/Israel/Babylon/Assyria etc. over a long period of time.  It really puts the historical time frame in perspective, but there's no real narrative so it's better as a reference book than anything.

-Heritage of Central Asia (Frye) - Really dry stuff, definitely for specialists in the region.  Don't bother reading it unless you can envision geography well in your mind.

-Ancient Persia (Wiesehofer) - Again, really dry stuff, clearly for specialists.  No real narrative, just focuses on the fragmentary evidence (a lot of it being archaeological or linguistic) relating to the three pre-Islamic Iranian empires.  I get the feeling a lot of German history is written this way.

-The Persian Empire (Allen) - Tons of pretty pictures, basically a coffee table history book.  A very good introductory book for people who don't know anything about the first Persian (Achaemenid) Empire, ending with Alexander the Great's conquest.

-Landmark Herodotus - A translation of Herodotus' massive histories.  Obviously it's not exactly...trustworthy, but it's still excellent stuff.

-The Great Arab Conquests (Kennedy) - A collection of the various narratives of the Islamic conquests in the Near East, Iran, the Maghreb, Spain, Central Asia, Sind, etc.  There's some annoying spelling errors and historical inaccuracies (he says at one point that the Roman Empire was at its height...in the 8th century), but it's an enjoyable read.  Also has a lot of interesting side stories.

-Shadows in the Desert (Farrokh) - Iranian history from an Iranian's perspective.  Pretty interesting, well written, and full of pretty pictures, even if Farrokh's nationalism pops through every now and then.

-Rome and Persia in Late Antiquity (Dignas) - Another good reference book but not particularly good reading material.  If you want a narrative, there's a billion other books that cover this stuff, I'm sure.
